By car, Richland's central business district is immediately off of Interstate 182 at Exit 5, George Washington Way.  The Tri-Cities are close to each other but a long way from anyone else: expect at least a 75 minute drive from

) is located in Pasco, roughly 10 miles east of Richland. There are daily flights to and from Seattle/Tacoma, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Denver, Salt Lake City, Phoenix, and Minneapolis/St.Paul.

hours=Most areas open from 2 hours before sunrise to 2 hours after sunset

content=The monumental Hanford nuclear fuel production site lies to the northwest of Richland, and strict security means that the land surrounding it was not developed — and became a surprising wildlife preserve. A National Monument since 2000, Hanford Reach covers thousands of acres in a giant U-shape along the Columbia River.
content=A large outcrop in the plains. Popular as a hang-gliding spot. A wildlife refuge since 1953, it became part of the Hanford Reach National Monument in 2000.

content=Five-hour tours of the Hanford Nuclear Site with stops at the historic B Reactor, the Environmental Restoration Disposal Facility, the Waste Treatment Plant construction zone. April through September only, and always on weekdays.  Reservations required on a first come-first serve basis — registration for the year's tours opens in early March, and often fills in less than a day.  Cancellations will open up a few slots, particularly later in the season, but you'll need luck to catch them when they happen: no waiting list.
This tour is only open to U.S. citizens.

content=Shorter tours visit only the B Reactor, the world's first large-scale nuclear reactor.  Like the site tours, advance reservations are necessary; 50 tour dates per year between April and September, including most weekends.  Groups will get about two hours on site, plus 45 minutes each way on a chartered bus to reach the isolated facility.  Unlike the full site tours, there is no citizenship requirement, but photo ID is mandatory.
content=Apollo offers a wide variety of fine Greek cuisine.  Take-out is available.

Richland doesn't have a large supply of hotels, and many of its travelers are on business at the Lab.  As a result, hotels can unexpectedly book out at any time of the year.
are generally quite convenient to Richland as well,

value: content=The budget end of the Hilton empire, it's a classic business hotel: nothing fancy, but the facilities are well maintained and the staff helpful.

content=The building is passing through dated and wrapping all the way back around to retro - don't overlook the long curving hallway, or the pickled wood ceilings on the upper floor.  Otherwise, a standard midrange hotel.  Rates are on the high side for what you get.
